fileDesc.extent: Approx. 33 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 8 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal licence. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The replication to the City of London's plea to the quo warranto brought against their charter by our Sovereign Lord the King in Michaelmas term, 1681
titleStmt.author: England and Wales.
Sawyer, Robert, Sir, 1633-1692.
England and Wales. Attorney-General.
London (England). City of London's plea to the quo warranto (an information) brought against their charter in Michaelmas term, 1681.

notesStmt.note: Reply brief, by Attorney-General Robert Sawyer, to the plea published in 1682 under title: The City of London's plea to the quo warranto (an information) brought against their charter in Michaelmas term, 1681.
Incorrectly identified on film as Wing R1074, which is located at reel position 2236:43.
Reproduction of original in the Huntington Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.head: Dominus Rex versus Majorem & Communitat. ac Cives Civitat. London.
div.p:
ET predict’ Robertus Sawyer Attorn. dict’ Domini Regis nunc General. qui pro eodem domino Rege nunc in hac parte sequitur quoad Placitum praefat’ Majoris & Communitat’ ac Civium Civitat’ predict’ quoad Libertat. Privilg. & Franches. predict’ per ipsos superius clamat’ (viz.) ipsos Majorem & Communitat’ ac Cives Civitat’ London. fore de seipsis unum Corpus Corporat’ & Politicum in re facto & nomine per nomen Majoris & Communitat’ ac Civium Civitat. London. ac per idem nomen placitare & implacitari respondere ac responderi superius placitat’ pro eodem Dom. Rege nunc dic’ quod per aliqua per prefat’ Majorem & Communitat. ac Cives Civitat. London. predict’ superius placitando allegat’ eadem Libertat. Privileg. & Franches. eisdem Majori & Communitat’ ac Civibus Civitat’ London.
predict’ allocari seu adjudicari non debent nec iidem Major & Communitas ac Cives de premis’ in Informac’ predict’ superius specificat’ exonerari debent quia dic’ quod Cives Civit’ London. predict’ à tempore cujus contrar’ memor’ homin’ non existit’ non fuer’ corpus corporat’ & politicum in re facto & nomine per nomen Majoris & Communitat’ ac Civium Civitat’ London. modo & forma prout prefat’ Major & Communitas ac Cives Civit’ London. predict’ superius placitando allegaver. Et hoc idem Attorn’ dict’ Dom. Regis nunc General’ pro eodem Dom. Rege nunc pet’ quod inquiratur per patriam. Et predict’ Robertus Sawyer Attorn’ dict’ Dom. Regis nunc General’ quoad placitum prefat’ Majoris & Communitat’ ac Civium Civit’ London. predict’ quoad Libertat. Privileg. & Franches. predict’ per ipsos superius clamat’ (viz.) ipsos Majorem & Communitat. ac Cives Civit’ London. fore de seipsis unum corpus corporat’ & politicum in re facto & nomine per nomen Majoris & Communitat’ ac Civium Civitat’ London. ac per idem nomen placitare & implacitari respondere ac responderi superius placitat’
ulterius dic’ quod per aliqua per prefat’ Majorem & Communitat’ ac Cives Civit’ London predict’ superius placitando allegat. Eedem Libertat. Privileg. & Franches. eisdem Majori & Communitat’ ac Civibus Civit’ London predict’ allocari seu adjudicari non debent nec iidem Major & Communitas ac Cives de premiss. in Informatione predict’ superius specificat’ exonerari debent, quia protestando quod Cives ejusdem Civitat’ a tempore cujus contrar’ memor’ homin’ non existit non fuer’ corpus corporat’ & politicum in re facto nomine per nomen Majoris & Communitat’ ac Civium Civit’ London, ac per idem nomen per totum tempus illud placitaver’ ac implacitat’ fuerunt responder’ ac respons’ fuer’ & placitare & implacitari respondere ac responderi a toto tempore supradict’ ufi fuer’ & consuever’ prout predict’ Major & Communitas ac Cives Civit’ London predict’ superius placitando allegaverunt pro placito tamen idem Attorn’ dict’ Dom. Regis nunc General’ pro eodem Domino Rege nunc ulterius dic’ quod predict’ Major & Communitas ac Cives Civit’ London
predict’ assumentes super se fore corpus corporat’ & politicum ac racione inde potestatem & authoritatem habere ad seipsos insimul convocand’ & assembland’ ad bona & salubria leges ordines & ordinac’ ones legibus & statutis hujus regni Angl’ minime repugnan’ sive contrar’ pro meliori regimine & gubernac’one Civit’ predict’ ac Civium & inhabitantium ejusdem Civitat’ ac pro conservac’one pacis Dom. Regis infra Civit’ predict’ iidem Major & Communitas ac Cives Civit’ London predict’ sub colore & pretextu inde eorum privatum lucrum & commodum solum respicien’ contra fiduciam in corpore corporato & politico per Dom. Regem & Leges hujus regni Anglie reposit’ assumpser’ illicitam & injustam potestatem & authoritat’ ad denar’ de subdit’ ac ligeis Dom. Regis nunc levand’ ad usum ipsorum Majoris & Communitat’ ac Civium Civitat. London predict’ propr’ colore legum sive Ordinaco’n’ per ipsos de facto ordinat. & stabilit’ abs{que} aliquo alio Jure Titulo sive Authoritate quibuscun{que} ac in prosecuc’on’ & execuc’on’ hujusmodi illegalis & injuste potestat’ & authoritat’ per ipsos sic usurpat’
iidem Major & Communitas ac Cives Civitat. London predict’ die Jovis decimo septimo die Septembris Anno Regni dict’ Dom. Regis nunc vicesimo sexto in eorum Communi Concilio adtunc tent’ in Camera Guihald Civit. London predict’ (viz.) in Paroch’ Sancti Michaelis Bassishaw, London, insimul Assemblat’ fuer’ condider’ & publicaver’ quandam Legem per ipsos de facto inactitat’ pro levac’one seperalium denar’ summar’ de omnibus subdit’ ac Ligeis Dom. Regis nunc tam liberis quam non liberis hominibus Civit’ predict’ & aliis extraneis ad publica Mercata infra Civitat’ predict’ tent’ acceden’ cum victual’ & provisionibus suis ibidem vendend’ (viz.) de qualibet persona pro quolibet onere equino Anglice Horse-load provision’ in aliquod public’ Mercat’ infra Civit’ predict’ per ipsum importat’ ibidem vendend’ duorum denar’ per diem & pro qualibet canistra Anglice Dosser provision’ in aliquod Mercat’ predict’ ibidem vendend’ importat’ unius denar’ per diem & pro qualibet Carectata provision’ tract’ cum non plur’ quam tribus equis in aliquod Mercat’ predict’ ibidem vendend’ importat’ quatuor denar’ per diem & pro qualibet Carectata provision’ tract’ cum quatuor equis vel plur’ in aliquod Mercat’ predict’ ibidem vendend’ importat’
sex denar’ per diem ac diversarum al’ denar’ sum’ de quibuslibet personis que aliqua victualia sive provision’ da Mercat’ infra Civit’ London predict’ seu eorum aliqua vel aliquod importarent ibidem vendend’ ac per eandem legem sic per eos illegalit’ fact’ iidem Major & Communit’ ac Cives Civit’ London predict’ de facto ordinaver’ quod eedem seperal’ denar’ summe solut’ forent ad propr’ opus & usum prefat’ Majoris & Communitat. ac Civium Civit. London predict’ ac quod si aliquis in Mercat’ predict’ existen’ cum victual’ sive provisionibus suis ibidem vendend’ recusaret sive differret solvere respectivas ratas predict’ tunc talis recusans sive differens amot’ foret • a loco suo in Mercat. predict’ Et ulterius idem Attorn. dict’ Dom. Regis nunc General’ pro eodem Dom. Rege nunc dic’ quod predict’ Major & Communitas ac Cives Civit. London predict. sub solo colore & pretextu legis predict’ sic per ipsos pro eorum privato lucro & commodo illegalit’ fact. & abs{que} aliquo alio jure Titulo sive Authoritate quibuscun{que} diversas ingentes denar. Summas in toto se attingen. ad quinque mille libras per annum per spacium septem annorum post predcit. decimum septimum diem Septembris Anno vicesimo sexto supradicto prox. sequen.
& amplius apud London predict. in Paroch. predict. de omnibus Dom. Regis ligeis & subditis ad publica Mercata per totum tempus predict. infra Civit. predict. tent. cum victualibus & provisionibus ibidem vendend. accedentibus erexer. levaver. & exigi & levari fecerunt & denarios illos ad eorum proprios usus converterunt & disposuerunt in subversionem boni regiminis et gubernac’onis Civitatis predict’ et in magnam oppressionem et depauperac’on. subditor. dict. Dom. Regis nunc ad Mercat. predict’ cum victualibus et provision. suis acceden. et venien. ad grave dampn. et nocument. omnium Ligeorum et Subdit. dict Dom. Regis in Augmentac. preciorum omnium victual. et provision. in Mercatis predict. vendit. ac in dict. Dom. Regis nunc et Corone sue Regie exheredac’on. manifestam ac contra fiduciam in Corpore Corporat. et Politico per Dom. Regem ac Leges hujus Regni Angl. reposit’ Et ulterus idem Attorn. dicti Dom. Regis nunc General’ pro eodem Domino Rege nunc dic’ quod ubi Sessio Parliamenti Dom. Regis nunc per Prorogac’on. tent’ fuit apud Westm. in Com. Middlesex. super vicesimum primum diem Octobris Anno Regni dicti Dom. Regis nunc tricesimo secundo
ac ibidem continuat’ us{que} decimum diem Januar’ tunc prox’ sequen’ ac super eodem decimo die Januarii anno regni dict’ Dom. Regis nunc tricesimo secundo supradict’ apud Westminst. predicti idem Parliamentum Prorogat’ fuit per dict’ Dom. Regem nunc us{que} vicesimum diem tunc Instantis Januar. predict’ Major et Communitas ac Cives Civitat’ London predict’ postea scil’ die Jovis decimo tertio die Januar’ Anno Regni dict’ Dom. Regis nunc tricesimo secundo supradict’ in eorum Communi Concilio tent’ in Camera Guihald Civit’ predict’ viz. in Paroch’ Sancti Michaelis Bassishaw London predict. Assemblat’ illicite malitiose advisate et seditiose et abs{que} aliqua legali authoritate in se assumpser’ ad censend’ et judicand’ dict’ Dom. Regem nunc et Prorogac’ on’ Parliamenti per dict’ Dom. Regem nunc sic fact’ Ac adtunc et ibidem iidem Major et Communitas ab Cives Civitat. London sic in eodem Communi Concilio Assemblat’ vota et suffragia sua deder’ et ordinaver’ quod quedam Petitio sub nomine Majoris Aldermannum et Commun’ Civit’ London in Communi Concil. Assemblat’ dicto Dom.
Regi nunc exhibit’ foret in qua quidem Peticone content. fuit quod per predict’ Prorogacon’ Parliamenti predict’ prosecuco’ Justic’ publice hujus regni ac preparaco’ Anglice the making provision necessar. preservacon. dicti Dom. Regis nunc ac ejus subditorum protestantium recepissent obstrucon’ Anglice Interrupcon’ et iidem Major et Communitas ac Cives Civitat. London predict’ in Communi Concilio predict’ sic ut prefertur Assemblat’ illicite malitiose advisate & seditiose & ea intencone quod eadem Petitio publicat’ & dispersa foret inter subditos dict’ Dom. Regis nunc fideles ad ipsos in opinion’ inducend’ quod idem Dominus Rex nunc per Prorogacon’ Parliamenti predict’ publicam Justic’ regni obstruxisset & ad eosdem Subditos dict’ Dom. Regis incitand’ in odium persone dict’ Dom. Regis & gubernacon. in hoc regno stabilit’ & ad perturband’ pacem & tranquillitat’ in hoc Regno Anglie adtunc & ibidem ordinaver’ quod eadem Petitio sic continen’ seditiosam & scandalosam materiam predict’ impress’ foret ac postea scil’ die & Anno ult. supradict’ apud London predict’
in Paroch’ predict’ eandem Peticon. ea intencone quod eadem publicat’ & dispers’ foret inter subdit’ dict. Dom. Regis nunc ad affectiones suas a dict’ Dom. Rege nunc & gubernacon’ sua alienand’ & divertend’ malitiose advisate & seditiose impresser’ & imprimi & publicari fecer’ & causaver’ in contempt’ & scandalum dict’ Dom. Regis nunc ac gubernacon’ sue hujus Regni Anglie ac in promocon. & excitacon. seditionis & perturbacon. pacis & tranquilitat’ infra hoc regnum Anglie & in pernitiosum aliorum dict’ Dom. Regis nunc Subdit’ & Ligeorum exemplum per quod idem Major & Communitas ac Cives Civitat’ London predict’ Libertat. Privileg. & Franches. predict’ fore de seipsis Corpus Corporat’ & Politicum per nomen Majoris & Communitat’ ac Civium Civitat’ London, forisfecer’ predict’ tamen Major & Communitas ac Cives Civitat’ London predict’ postea scil’ per tempus superius in Informacone predict’ specificat’ Libertat. Privileg. & Franches. ill’ super dict’ Dom. Regem nunc usurpaver’ & adhuc usurpant
prout per Informacon. predict’ superius versus eos supponitur. Et hoc idem Attorn’ dict’ Dom. Regis nunc General’ pro eodem Domino Rege nunc parat’ est verificare unde petit’ judicium & quod predict’ Major & Communitas ac Cives Civitat’ London de premiss, predict’ Convincantur ac de Libertat. Privileg. & Franches. ill’ abdicantur & excludantur &c. Et quoad placitum prefat’ Majoris & Communitat’ ac Civium Civitat’ London predict’ quoad Libertat. Privileg. & Franches. predict. per ipsos superius clamat’ (viz.) ipsos habere Vice-comit’ Civit. & Com. Civit. London & Vice-comit’ Com. Midd. & nominare & eligere ex seipsis duas personas fore Vicecomit’ Civit. predict. & Com. ejusdem Civit. & Vicecomit. Com. Midd. Ac illos sic nominat. & elect. preficere & constituere Vic’ Civit. predict. & Com. ejusdem Civit. & Vic’ Com. Midd. Ac ut Vicecomit’ Civitat’ predict’ & Com. ejusdem Civitat. ad execucon. et retorn’ omnium Brevium Billarum et precept’ Dom. Regis pro administracon. et execucon. Justicie
infra Civit predict. et Com. ejusdem Civit. exequend. faciend. que ad Officium Vic’ faciend. pertinent’ ac ad faciend. et exequend. omnia et singula. alia infra Civit’ predict’ & Com’ ejusdem Civit’ que ad officium Vicecom. faciend’ pertinent ac ut Vicecom. Com. Middlesex pro eodem Com. deservitur. ac omnia Brevia Billas & precept’ Dom. Regis infra Com. Middlesex pro administracone & execucone Justicie ibidem et exequend’ & retorn’ inde faciend’ que ad Officium Vic’ faciend’ pertinent. superius placitat: Necnon quoad placitum prefat’ Majoris & Communitat’ ac Civium Civitat’ London predict’ quoad Libertat’ Privileg’ & Franches’ per ipsos superius clamat’ (Viz.) Major dict’ Civitat’ & hujusmodi Alderman’ ejusdem Civitat’ qui Officium Majorat’ Civit’ illius sustinuer’ ac inde fuer’ dimissi ac tres Alderman’ sen’ Civit’ predict’ qui diutius in Officio Alderman’ Civit’ predict’ steter’ & onus & Officium Majorat’ Civit’ non sustinuer’ fore Justiciar’ Dom. Regis ad pacem infra Civit’ predict’ conservandum ac ad Session. pacis & placita Corone (Scilicet) talia placita Corone qual’ Justiciar’ Dom.
Regis ad pacem conservand’ assign’ ligittime tenere possent infra eandem Civitat’ tenend’ ac ad omnia Felon’ Riot’ Rout’ & Conventicul’ illicit’ infra Civitat’ predict’ inquirend’ audiend’ & terminand’ superius placitat’ idem Attorn’ Dom. Regis nunc General’ qui &c. pet’ licenc’ inde interloquend’ coram Dom. Rege usque a die Sancti Michaelis in tres septimanas ubicun{que} &c. Et ei conceditur’ idem dies dat’ est prefat’ Major Communitat’ ac Civibus Civit’ London predict’ &c.

div.head: The King against the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London.
div.p:
AND the said Robert Sawyer Attorney General of our said Lord the King that now is, who for our Lord the King on this behalf prosecuteth: As to the Plea of the said Major and Commonalty and Citizens of the City aforesaid, as to the Liberties, Priviledges and Franchises aforesaid, by them above claimed, to wit, That they the said Major, Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, are of themselves one Body Corporate and Politick, in matter, fact and name, by the name of Major and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, and by the same name to plead and be impleaded, to answer and be answered, as is above pleaded: He the said Attorney General for the said Lord the King saith, That for any thing by the said Major and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, above in pleading alledged: The said Liberties, Privileges and Franchises ought not to be allowed or adjudged to the same Major and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City
of London aforesaid: Neither ought the said Major and Commonalty and Citizens to be discharged from the premisses in the Information aforesaid specified, because he saith, That the Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, from the time whereof the memory of Man is not to the contrary, were not a Body Corporate and Politick, in matter, fact, and name, by the name of Major and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London, in manner and form as the said Major and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, above in pleading have alledged: And this the said Attorney General of our said Lord the King that now is for our said Lord the King prays, That it may be enquired of by the Countrey. And the said Robert Sawyer Attorney General of our said Lord the King that now is, as to the Plea of the said Mayor and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, as to the Liberties, Priviledges and Franchises aforesaid, by them above claimed (to wit) That they the said Mayor and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London, are of themselves one Body Corporate and Politick in Matter, Fact and Name, by the Name of Mayor and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London, and by the same Name to Plead, and be
Impleaded, to Answer, and be Answered, as is above Pleaded: He further saith, That by any thing by the said Mayor and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, before in pleading alledged: The same Liberties, Priviledges and Franchises ought not to be allowed and adjudged to the said Mayor and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, neither ought the same Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens to be discharged of the premisses in the Information aforesaid specified, because by protestation that the Citizens of the same City, from the time whereof the memory of Man is not to the contrary, were not a Body Corporate and Politick in Matter, Fact and Name, by the name of Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, and by the same name for all that time have Pleaded, and were Impleaded, and have Answered, and were Answered, and to Plead, and be Impleaded, to Answer, and to be Answered for, by all the time aforesaid have used and accustomed in such manner as the said Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid above in pleading have alledged: Notwithstanding for Plea the said Attorney General of our said Lord the King, for our said Lord the King further saith, That the said Mayor and Commonalty
and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid assuming upon themselves to be a Body Corporate and Politick, and by reason thereof to have power and authority to Call and Assemble themselves together for the making good and wholesome Laws, Orders and Ordinances not repugnant nor contrary to the Laws and Statutes of this Kingdom of England, for the better rule and government of the City aforesaid, and of the Citizens and Inhabitants of the said City, and for the keeping of the Kings Peace within the said City: The said Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, under colour and pretence thereof respecting only their own private gain and profit, contrary to the confidence reposed in a Body Corporate and Politick by our Lord the King, and the Laws of this Kingdom of England, have assumed an unlawful, and unjust Power and Authority to Levy Money of the Subjects, and Leige-people of our Lord the King that now is, to the proper use of the said Mayor and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, by colour of the Laws or Ordinances by them in fact ordained and established, without any other Right, Title or Authority whatsoever: And in prosecution, and Execution of such illegal and unjust Power and Authority
by them so usurped, They the said Mayor and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, on Thursday the Seventeenth day of September, in the Six and Twentieth Year of the Reign of our said Lord the King that now is, in their Common-Council then held in the Chamber of the Guild-hall of the City of London aforesaid, to wit, in the Parish of St. Michael Bassishaw, London, being Assembled together, did make, and publish a certain Law, by them in fact Enacted, for the Levying several Sums of Money of all his Majesties Subjects and Leige-People, as well Free as not Free-men of the said City, and other Forreigners, at the publick Markets held within the City aforesaid, coming thither to sell their Victuals, and Provisions (to wit) of every person for every Horse-load of Provisions, by him brought into any publick Market of the said City, there to be sold, Two Pence by the day, and for every Dosser of Provision brought into any Market aforesaid, there to be sold, One Penny by the day, and for every Cart-load of Provisions drawn with no more then three Horses, brought into any Market aforesaid, there to be sold, Four Pence by the day, and for every Cart-Load of Provisions drawn with Four Horses or more, brought into any Market aforesaid, there to be sold,
Six-pence by the day, and of divers other Sums of Money of whatsoever persons should bring any Victuals or Provisions to the Markets within the City of London aforesaid, or some of them, or any thing there to be sold, and by the same Law so by them illegally made, the said Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, in fact have Ordained, That the said several Sums of money should be paid to the proper use and behoof of them the said Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid: And that if any person being in the Markets aforesaid with Victuals or Provisions there to be sold, should refuse or defer to pay the respective Rates aforesaid, that then such person so refusing or deferring, should be removed from his place in the said Market. And the said Attorney-General of our said Lord the King that now is further saith, That the said Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, under the sole Colour and pretence of the Law aforesaid so by them for their private gain and profit illegally made, and without any other Right, Title or Authority whatsoever, divers great Sums of money in the whole amounting to 5000 l. yearly by the space of Seven Years after the said Seventeenth day of September in the Six and twentieth year aforesaid next
ensuing, and more at London aforesaid in the Parish aforesaid of all the Liege-People and Subjects of our Lord the King, coming to the Publick Markets held for all the before-mentioned time within the said City, with Provisions and Victuals there to be sold, have exacted, levied, and caused to be exacted and levied, and the same Money they have converted and disposed of to their own use, In subversion of the good Rule and Government of the said City, and to the great oppression and impoverishing of the Subjects of our said Lord the King coming to the said Markets with their Victuals & Provisions, And to the great dammage and hurt of all the Liege-People and Subjects of our said Lord the King, to the encreasing and raising of the Prices of all Victuals and Provisions sold in the Markets aforesaid: And to the manifest disheriting of our said Lord the King that now is; And contrary to the Confidence reposed in a Body Corporate and Politick by our Lord the King and the Laws of this Realm of England: And the said Attorney-General of our said Lord the King that now is, for our said Lord the King further saith, That whereas a Session of Parliament of our Lord the King that now is, was held at Westminster in the County of Middlesex by Prorogation upon the One and twentieth day of October, in the Two and Thirtieth
Year of his said now Majesties Reign, And there continued untill the 10th day of January then next ensuing, and upon the same tenth day of January, in the two and thirtieth Year of his said Majesties Reign, at Westminster aforesaid, the same Parliament was Prorogued by our Lord the King that now is, until the 20th day of the then Instant of January, The said Mayor and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid afterwards, to wit, On Thursday the Thirteenth day of January, in the two and thirtieth Year of his said now Majesties Reign, in their Common Council held in their Council Chamber at Guild-hall of the City aforesaid, to wit, in the Parish of St. Michael Bassishaw, London aforesaid, being Assembled, did unlawfully, maliciously, advisedly and sediciously, and without any Legal Authority assume upon themselves to censure and judge our said Lord the King that now is, and the Prorogation of the Parliament so made by our said Lord the King that now is; And then and there they the said Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, so Assembled in their Common Council, did then Vote and Ordain, That a certain Petition under the Name of the Mayor, Aldermen and Commons of the City of London in the Common Council Assembled, should be exhibited to our
said Lord the King that now is, in which Petition there was contained, That by the said Prorogation of the Parliament aforesaid, the prosecution of the publick Justice of this Kingdom, and the making provision necessary for the preservation of our said Lord the King that now is, and of his Protestant Subjects, received interruption, and the said Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, in the Common Council aforesaid, so as aforesaid Assembled, unlawfully, maliciously, advisedly, and seditiously, and to the intent that the same Petition might be published and dispersed abroad amongst his now Majesties faithful Subjects, to induce them into the opinion, That our said Lord the King that now is, by Prorogation of the Parliament aforesaid had obstructed the publick Justice of the Kingdom, and to incite the same Subjects of our said Lord the King that now is, to the hatred of the Person of our said Lord the King, and of his Government Establish'd in this Kingdom, and to disturb the Peace and Tranquility of this Kingdom of England; they then and there did Ordain, That the same Petition containing the seditious and scandalous matter aforesaid should be Imprinted: And afterwards, to wit, The day and year last aforesaid at
London aforesaid, in the Parish aforesaid, the same Petition to the intent that the same might be published and dispersed amongst the Subjects of our said Lord the King that now is, to alienate and divert their affections from our said Lord the King that now is, and from his Government, they malitiously, advisedly and seditiously did Print, and cause to be Imprinted and Published to the contempt and scandal of our said Lord the King that now is, and of his Government of this Kingdom of England, and to the promoting and raising of Sedition, and disturbance of the Peace and Tranquility within this Kingdom of England, and to the pernicious example of others his Majesties Subjects and Leige-people; by which the said Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid have forfeited the Liberties, Priviledges, and Franchises aforesaid, to be of themselves a Body Corporate and Politick, by the Name of Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London: Yet the aforesaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, afterwards (to wit) by all the time in the Information aforesaid specified, have usurped upon our Lord the King, and yet do usurp those Liberties, Priviledges and Franchises,
so as by the Information aforesaid against them is supposed: And this the said Attorney General of our said Lord the King that now is, for our said Lord the King is ready to aver, wherefore he prays Judgment, and that the said Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London may be convicted of the premisses aforesaid, and be excluded from, and forejudged their Liberties, Priviledges, and Franchises, &c. And as to the Plea of the said Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid: As to the Liberties, Priviledges and Franchises aforesaid by them before claimed (to wit) That they have Sheriffs of the City, and County of the City of London, and a Sheriff of the County of Middlesex, and that they Nominate and Chuse out of themselves two persons to be Sheriffs of the City aforesaid, and County of the said City and Sheriff of the County of Middlesex; And to make and constitute those persons so Nominated and Elected Sheriffs of the City aforesaid, and of the County of the said City, and Sheriff of the County of Middlesex: And as Sheriffs of the City aforesaid, and County of the said City, to Execute and Return all the Writs, Bills and Precepts of our Lord the King, for the Administration and Execution of Justice within
the said City, and the County of the said City, to be executed and done, which do appertain to the Office of a Sheriff to be done: And to do and execute all and singular other things within the said City and County of the said City, which appertain to the Office of a Sheriff to be done: And as Sheriff of the County of Middlesex to serve for the same County; And to Execute and make Retorns of all the Writs, Bills and Prccepts of our Lord the King, within the County of Middlesex, for the Administration and Execution of Justice there to be executed and returned, appertaining to the Office of a Sheriff to be done before pleaded. And also as to the Plea of the said Mayor and Commonalty, and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, as to the Liberties, Priviledges, and Franchises by them before claimed (to wit) The Mayor of the said City, and such Aldermen of the same City who had born the Office of Mayor of that City, and from thence were dismissed: And Three Senior Aldermen of the said City, who had stood longer in the Office of an Alderman, and had never born the Burthen and Office of Mayor of the said City, should be Justices of our Lord the King to keep the Peace within the City; And at the Sessions of the Peace and Pleas of the Crown (to wit) such Pleas of
the Crown as the Justices of our Lord the King assigned to keep the Peace, might Lawfully hold within the said City to be held, And to enquire, hear, and determine of all Felonies, Riots, Routs, and unlawful Conventicles within the said City before pleaded: The said Attorney General of our Lord the King, who &c. prays License to Imparle before our Lord the King until from the day of St. Michael in Three weeks wheresoever, &c. and it is granted unto him. The same day is given to the said Major, Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London aforesaid, &c.
